messages.message: @lenny @Kerry is this just the celery-app-tasks or a different image or image(s) that need to be sent out? Confirming to ensure that we are getting the right images over.

we should send them all of the images. there have been other cherrypicks to the 22.01.0 branch that are included here as well, so to ensure we don't have any compatibility mismatches they should do a full upgrade
Hmmm… these cherrypicks are related to what we were seeking around the scheduler changes or just cherrypicks with bug fixes in general?
It’s a lot of effort getting all the images approved
by their cyber team and then going ahead with the upgrade…

I'll let @Kerry make a decision here...I believe our policy going forward is to always send a full set of images when upgrading. the images that are directly relevant to this change are job-service, webapp, and api-server-apps

the reason we prefer to send all images is that if one of the other 22.01 cherrypicks makes a compatibility-breaking change in another service, that will cause errors in their deployment and will result in a longer back and forth to debug and isolate the issue — we've had a few incidents related to this in the past

For 1-2 images, we take weeks to get approval to go ahead and now we’re saying we need to send a bunch of 30 images through scanning + vulnerability approval/exception and then finally deploy. We’re looking at a possible month lost…

We need to ship the full set of images, otherwise it’s very risky and very hard for us to support. We now run vulnerability scan internally daily so we can share our vulnerability report to you if that helps with the process. @shaunak - can you share how we can get access to the internal vulnerability report? @Steve Jenner This is what we were talking about in the meeting.

@Kerry hsbc and other customers have pipelines built to automatically scan and approve images... Our reports can be shared but won't stop their scans from being run... And 30+ images will definitely have back and forth...
While I will present the situation to HSBC that all images are to be pulled in, I expect it's not going to help our case as by the time the images get approved we'll be at go-live time...
The scan reports are in <#C02Q8S53J10|> but those don't have our comments (exceptions, non-actionable vulns, planned fixes) attached

It looks like the scan report is not helpful anyways, customers might not care about it since they have their own scanning pipeline. @Varun Rao, I was in a meeting with CS / GTM leaders, and in that meeting we establish that the standard is to not backport features and not ship partial services unless we have an exception. Can you escalate to your manager and Steve to get an exception there. If we have to do it in this case, please have them reach out to me.
If we can ship all images, they are ready to go and we can proceed

I'll explore all options @Kerry and keep you posted if any additional assistance is needed on this... If we're going with all it might be possible we'll go for an upgrade to 22.05... but I am concious of the timelines and it's impact on go live

So if the vulnerability scan process is automated then what is going to take the additional time in the HSBC process?  Ultimately shipping all images is intended to provide a more stable platform and reduce the number of unique environments we have to support.  This is a benefit to HSBC

There's a two step process for just the import of images plus remediation of vulns:

Step 1: scan every image for license
Step 2: scan for vulnerability
Step 3: remediate vulnerability

Step 1 and step 3 take away a lot of the time and involve a  lot of back and forth.
